                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Task-Deducing expression n(n+1)/2 for the series 1+2+3+4...
Procedure-Take a square of side n unit.Fill maximum no. of square with unit length, unit breadth and unit height.Now shade n no. of squares at the base, n-1 no. of squares in the 2nd row from the base.Continue like this till all rows are shaded in this way. 
Observation-Now you shall see the pattern  1+2+3+4... appearing.
Reasoning-If we find the shaded area it is equivalent to finding what is 1+2+3+4... .To do this-
Step 1-remove n no. of squares.Step2- observing that the remaining shaded portion is the half of a rectangle we can get the no. of shaded squares dividing the area of rectangle by 2,that is length(breadth)/2 or n(n-1)/2.
Step 3-adding base squares(n no. of squares) we get expression n+n(n-1)/2.
Simplifying it we get n(n+1)/2.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A well known rule for whether a number is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is whether the sum of its digits is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This can be extended to:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\bmod3=\text{digital root}(n)\bmod3"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
This is easily proven by the fact that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^n\div1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has a remainder of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for any positive integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". For example, we'll look at the number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"478"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}478\bmod3&=[400+70+8]\bmod3\\
&=[4\times(100\bmod3)+7\times(10\bmod3)+8]\bmod3\\
&=[4\times(1)+7\times(1)+8]\bmod3\\
&=[4+7+8]\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
So to find the remainder on dividing by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of the large number in the question, we will find the remainder on dividing by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of the digital root of the number:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"122333444455555666666\dots10000000001000000000\dots1000000000\bmod3\\
=\text{digital root}(122333444455555666666\dots10000000001000000000\dots1000000000)\bmod3\\
=(1+2+2+3+3+3+4+4+4+4+\dots+1000000000+1000000000+\dots+1000000000)\bmod3\\
=(1+2\times2+3\times3+4\times4+\dots+1000000000\times1000000000)\bmod3\\
=(1+2^2+3^2+4^2+5^2+6^2+\dots+1000000000^2)\bmod3\\
=[(1\bmod3)+(2^2\bmod3)+(3^2\bmod3)+(4^2\bmod3)+(5^2\bmod3)+(6^2\bmod3)+\dots+(1000000000^2\bmod3)]\bmod3"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Now we have to see what remainder we get from each term on dividing by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\bmod3=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^2\bmod3=\textbf{0}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\bmod3=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^2\bmod3=(n\bmod3)^2\bmod3=1\bmod3=\textbf{1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\bmod3=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^2\bmod3=(n\bmod3)^2\bmod3=2^2\bmod3=4\bmod3=\textbf{1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This means we get a pattern of 1s and 0s in our sum:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[(1\bmod3)+(2^2\bmod3)+(3^2\bmod3)+(4^2\bmod3)+(5^2\bmod3)+(6^2\bmod3)+\dots+(1000000000^2\bmod3)]\bmod3\\
=1+1+0+1+1+0+1+1+0+\dots+1+1+0+1\bmod3"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Since 1000000000 divided by 3 gives 333333333 with remainder 1, our sum equals:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[(1+1+0)\times333333333+(1000000000^2\bmod3)]\bmod3\\
=(2\times333333333+1)\bmod3\\
=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Since 333333333 is divisible by three, this term disappears when taking the remainder on dividing by three, leaving only the 1 from the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000000000^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore the final answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"
